data.author: Hiral Goyal
data.content: NASA Administrator Bill Nelson warned that China may try to claim territory on Moon and said, "We better watch out that they don't get to a place on the Moon under the guise of scientific research." Stating that "we're in a space race", he added, "It isn't beyond the realm of possibility that...[China] says, 'We're here, this is our territory'."
data.title: China may try to claim territory on the Moon, warns NASA Chief

data.author: Pragya Swastik
data.content: 'Danuri', South Korea’s first-ever spacecraft to orbit the Moon, sent back images of the lunar surface and the Earth beyond. On December 28, 2022, it took an image of Earth when it was 124 km above the Moon. 'Danuri', a portmanteau of the Korean words 'Moon' and 'Enjoy', was launched on a SpaceX rocket from the US in August 2022.
data.title: Pic shows Earth from 124 km above the Moon

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: American space agency NASA has shared a video, captured by its Orion spacecraft, which shows the Earth rising behind the Moon. The video was captured by the spacecraft on November 28, as it reached its farthest distance from home, NASA said. The video, that was sped up 900 times, was captured during the Artemis I Moon mission test flight.
data.title: NASA shares video showing the Earth rising behind the Moon

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: South Korea has reported its first case of infection and death from Naegleria fowleri, commonly referred to as 'brain-eating amoeba', health authorities said on Monday. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency (KDCA) confirmed that a Korean national in his 50s died after returning from Thailand. The man died 10 days after displaying symptoms of the rare infection.
data.title: South Korea reports its 1st death from 'brain-eating amoeba'

data.author: Pragya Swastik
data.content: Every planet in the solar system was visible in the night sky at the same time in a rare astronomical event on Wednesday. While Venus, Mercury, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars could be seen in the northern hemisphere with the naked eye, Uranus and Neptune, were better viewed with binoculars. All the planets appeared only 1.5 degrees apart on Wednesday night.
data.title: All planets in the solar system visible at the same time in night sky in rare event

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: A picture shared by NASA shows the planets Venus, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars simultaneously visible from Earth. Taken late last month by Tunc Tezel in a village in Turkey, the image also captures the Moon and planet Mercury. Below visibility were the planets Neptune and Uranus, making this a nearly all-planet panorama, wrote NASA.
data.title: Pic shows several planets visible at the same time from Earth

data.author: Apaar Sharma
data.content: A comet that last appeared in the sky when Neanderthals roamed the Earth is set to make its reappearance next year. The C/2022 E3 (ZTF) comet orbits the sun every 50,000 years and will pass within 26 million miles of Earth on February 2, making it visible to naked eyes. It's already visible using telescopes when the skies are clear.
data.title: Comet last seen during the Ice Age to pass Earth in early 2023

data.author: Pragya Swastik
data.content: Japanese astronaut Koichi Wakata took to Twitter to share a video of the first sunrise of 2023 as seen from space. The astronaut called it a "miraculous moment". Koichi Wakata, currently onboard the International Space Station, welcomed the new year with fellow astronauts from the US, Europe, and Russia.
data.title: Astronaut shares video of the first sunrise of 2023 from space

data.author: Srishty Choudhury
data.content: Union Science and Technology Minister Jitendra Singh on Sunday said that science, technology and innovation in 2023 will define India's picture in 2047. Speaking on the '2023 Science Vision', he said, "2023 holds significance because 2023 would outline India's form in 2047." He added, "The future belongs to those who have innovative ideas and out-of-box goals."
data.title: Science, innovation in 2023 to define India's form in 2047: Jitendra Singh

data.author: Mansi Agarwal
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday virtually inaugurated 108th Indian Science Congress and said the country has plenty of data and technology at present. "These can take India's science to new heights," he stated. "Data analysis is rapidly moving ahead. It helps in converting information into insight and analysis into actionable knowledge," he added.
data.title: India's data and tech can take science to new heights: PM Modi

data.author: Mansi Agarwal
data.content: SpaceX on Wednesday launched 54 Starlink internet satellites from Florida's Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in the firm's 60th mission of this year. "This...marks the first [launch] of Starlink's upgraded network...We're now able to deploy satellites to new orbits that will add even more capacity to the network," SpaceX said. The company conducted a total of 31 launches last year.
data.title: SpaceX launches 54 Starlink satellites in its 60th mission of 2022

data.author: Ananya Goyal
data.content: Russia's space agency said it's considering a "rescue" plan to send an empty spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) to bring back three crew members ahead of schedule. The Soyuz spacecraft that took them to the ISS suffered a coolant leak recently. Even though no astronauts were endangered, it's not clear if the leaky spacecraft can bring them back.
data.title: May send empty spacecraft to ISS to rescue crew: Russia amid Soyuz leak

data.author: Ananya Goyal
data.content: Indian-American Rajeev Badyal is among 30 members selected by US Vice President Kamala Harris to serve on the National Space Council Users' Advisory Group (UAG). The UAG provides the council advice on matters related to space policy and strategy. Badyal presently leads Amazon's Project Kuiper, which aims to increase global broadband access through a constellation of low Earth Orbit satellites.
data.title: Indian-American Rajeev Badyal chosen for US space council position

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: Archaeologists have uncovered 13 full and fragmentary projectile points in Idaho that are thousands of years older than any previously found in the Americas, Oregon State University reported. The projectile points are from roughly 15,700 years ago and range from about half an inch to 2 inches long. The projectile points were uncovered over multiple summers between 2012 and 2017.
data.title: Oldest known projectile points in the Americas uncovered: Report

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Life could be found on ice moon Enceladus, one of Saturn's 83 moons, as it produces methane, a study stated. The evidence of alien life could be found by a robot spacecraft sampling plumes jetting out of Enceladus' liquid interior. NASA had earlier found that a thick layer of ice hides a vast, warm saltwater ocean outgassing methane on Enceladus.
data.title: Alien life could be found on Saturn ice moon: Study

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: NASA's Perseverance Mars Rover has dropped the second rock sample tube on the Martian surface. The tube holds a piece of sedimentary rock. It is the longest rock core Perseverance has taken to date. The rock core is called 'Mageik' and was drilled out of a rock feature called 'Amalik' from the Jezero crater called 'Delta front'.
data.title: NASA's rover deposits second rock sample tube on Mars

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A recently discovered comet, dubbed C/2022 E3 (ZTF), is all set to make its closest approach to Earth on February 2. The comet is expected to be visible to the naked eye under dark skies and with a telescope or even with binoculars. The comet could come within 43 million kilometres of Earth.
data.title: Potential naked-eye comet to make close approach to Earth on Feb 2

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: China has released a small test satellite into orbit from its recently completed Tiangong space station. The 12-kilogramme satellite, the Macao Student Science Satellite 1, was released on December 18. The satellite carries both optical camera and radio payloads. It will be used by students in Macao for learning about Earth imaging, radio communication and other spaceflight activities.
data.title: China's space station releases small test satellite into orbit

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: Rare underwater "marimo" algae balls are at risk of being killed by sunlight, a University of Tokyo study said. The world's largest marimo can be found in Lake Akan in Japan, where they are sheltered by a thick layer of ice and snow. However, the ice is now thinning. Marimo can grow up to 30 centimetres in diameter.
data.title: Rare underwater marimo algae balls at risk from sunburn: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: NASA's Apollo 7 astronaut Walter Cunningham died aged 90 on Tuesday in Houston. Cunningham's family, through a spokesperson, informed that he died in the hospital of natural causes. He was the last surviving member of the three-astronaut crew aboard Apollo 7, the 11-day spaceflight which marked the first successful crewed space mission in NASA's Apollo program.
data.title: Walter Cunningham, the last surviving astronaut from Apollo 7, dies at 90

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: NASA astronauts Frank Rubio and Josh Cassada installed and deployed the International Space Station's fourth roll-out solar array, iROSA, during a seven-hour and eight-minute spacewalk on December 23. It was the 257th spacewalk in support of space station assembly, upgrades and maintenance. The iROSAs will increase the station's total available power from 160 kilowatts to up to 215 kilowatts.
data.title: NASA astronauts deploy 4th roll-out solar array on spacewalk outside ISS

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: Diving birds like penguins, puffins and cormorants may be more prone to extinction than non-diving birds, a University of Bath study has said. This is because they are highly specialised and therefore less able to adapt to changing environments than other birds. Less than a third of the 727 species of water birds use diving as a method of food-seeking.
data.title: Diving birds like penguins may be more prone to extinction: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Scientists have discovered a giant crocodile ancestor species in Brazil that lived alongside titanosaur dinosaurs about 72 and 66 million years ago. Named Titanochampsa iorii, the dinosaur was between 3m and 6m long and had a very strong bite, the study stated. It likely showed semiaquatic behaviour inhabiting an arid or semiarid environment, it added.
data.title: Giant crocodile with very strong bite that lived with dinosaurs found in Brazil

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: An NGO in Belgium recycles human hair using a machine that turns them into square-shaped mats, which can be used to absorb oil and other hydrocarbons. These mats can also be made into bio-composite bags. According to the project co-founder, these mats can be placed in drains to soak up pollutants in water before it is discharged into a river.
data.title: Human hair recycled in Belgium, can be used to absorb pollutants in environment

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers have discovered six new species of frogs that are smaller in size than a penny in Mexico. The male members of one of these species, named Craugastor candelariensis, can grow only up to 13 mm. These are direct-developing frogs that don't hatch as tadpoles but as fully-formed frogs. They live in the dark, humid leaf litter of the forests.
data.title: 6 new species of frogs smaller than a penny discovered in Mexico
